newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech says to limit ethylene supplies.
newsitem.headline: Czech says to limit ethylene supplies.

text.p: Czech petrochemcial concern Chemopetrol a.s. on Monday said it would limit supplies of ethylene products to strategic suppliers until November 30, after fire ravaged one of the refineries at its complex over the weekend.
Chemopetrol said in a statement that ethylene production would be limited to "strategic partners Spolana Neratovice and Bohlen in Germany".
It added that Kaucuk a.s. would continue to receive ethylbenzene supplies, though "less than normal amounts".
It said that Synthesia and Lovochemie would stop receiving ammonia supplies, but that Chemopetrol would provide tankers to help the firms receive supplies from other sources.

On Saturday, an explosion ripped through the Litvonov oil refinery -- partly owned by an international oil consortium -- starting a fire visible for several kilometres (milea) away which sent dense smoke rolling into neighbouring Germany.
The refinery's owner, Ceska Rafinerska a.s., said it would not be necessary to use state crude reserves despite the indefinite closure of one of the country's two main refineries.

In February this year, the IOC consortium of Du Pont de Nemours unit Conoco, Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Italy's Agip SpA paid $173 million for a 49 percent stake in Ceska Rafinerska a.s., a company set up to operate the two oil refineries at Litvinov and Kralupy.
